media_group.media_description:

Anton√≠n Dvo≈ô√°k
Symphony No. 8 "English Symphony"
Orquesta Reino de Arag√≥n
Conductor: Ricardo Casero

The Symphony No. 8 in G major, Op. 88, B. 163, is a symphony by Anton√≠n Dvo≈ô√°k, composed in 1889 at Vysok√° u P≈ô√≠bramƒõ, Bohemia, on the occasion of his election to the Bohemian Academy of Science, Literature and Arts. Dvo≈ô√°k conducted the premiere in Prague on 2 February 1890. In contrast to other symphonies of both the composer and the period, the music is cheerful and optimistic. It was originally published as Symphony No. 4.

Dvo≈ô√°k tried to achieve a marked difference to his Symphony No. 7, a stormy romantic work. No. 8 would be: "different from the other symphonies, with individual thoughts worked out in a new way". The Eighth is cheery and lyrical and draws its inspiration more from the Bohemian folk music that Dvo≈ô√°k loved.

Dvo≈ô√°k kept the typical format of a symphony in four movements, but structured them in an unusual way. All movements show a remarkable variety of themes, many of them based on Bohemian material. Occasionally the development of the themes seems like improvisation.

I. Allegro con brio (G minor ‚Üí G major)
II. Adagio (E‚ô≠ major ‚Üí C minor ‚Üí C major)
III. Allegretto grazioso ‚Äî Molto vivace (G minor ‚Üí trio and coda in G major)
IV. Allegro ma non troppo (G major)

Dvo≈ô√°k had the London firm of Vincent Novello publish the symphony in 1890, because he had disagreements with his regular publisher Fritz Simrock, who was more interested in shorter works as moneymakers. Simrock wanted to publish the movement titles and the composer's name in German, which Dvo≈ô√°k refused as a "proud Bohemian". Because of the country of its first publication, this symphony has occasionally been known as the "English" symphony, though "it would be more correct to call it the 'Czech', at least in comparison with its predecessor in D minor which was modelled more on Brahms."

Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
Oboe Concerto in C major, K. 314 / 271k
Orquesta Reino de Arag√≥n
Conductor: Ricardo Casero
Oboe: Mariano Esteban

Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's Oboe Concerto in C major, K. 314 (271k), was composed in the spring or summer of 1777, for the oboist Giuseppe Ferlendis (1755‚Äì1802) from Bergamo. In 1778, Mozart re-worked it as a concerto for flute in D major. The concerto is a widely studied piece for both instruments and is one of the most important concertos in the oboe repertoire.

As with his Flute Concerto No. 1, the piece is orchestrated for a standard string section (violin I/II, viola and cello/double bass doubling the bass line), two oboes, and two horns in D/C. The first and last movements are in the home key of C major, while the second movement is in the subdominant key of F major.

The piece is divided into three movements:

I. Allegro aperto
II. Adagio non troppo
III. Rondo: Allegretto
